text: I'm Matt Reeves director of dawn of the
Planet of the Apes in the sequence with
Jason Clark ascending the mountain to
the ape compound it was sort of a an
intention to change the point of view of
the movie you've been watching through
the point of view of the Apes who you
get emotionally connected to and the
idea was that as Jason came up here to
talk to Caesar that that point of view
would shift almost as if you'd seen a
story inside of a zoo and then you saw a
human being
step into that zoo and so suddenly he
would be surrounded by gorillas apes
chimps and would be a terrifying
situation we shot this in Vancouver in a
quarry that James chin Lennar brilliant
production designer convert it was very
hard sort of area to shoot it looks kind
of like it was sort of what it looks
like to shoot in very difficult but
Jason was actually surrounded for the
most part by no one I had recorded these
ape sounds that he was supposed to react
to and the recorder didn't work so
instead it was mostly me screaming at
him going and he was reacting to to
pretty much nothing here he is actually
being carried by stuntmen and the Apes
are then covering the stuntmen but for
the most part like as he's being thrown
here the stuntmen have thrown him down
but then as we step out into the
courtyard which was a set that we built
in New Orleans outside a completely
abandoned Six Flags that was destroyed
in Katrina this space here had no one in
it we'd shot a bunch of takes where he
had actors to respond to but by the time
we got to this part which was maybe take
a hundred he had to respond to nothing
and so Jason looks freaked out and he's
playing all that but there's actually no
one around him
Oh
